metadata.title: Early Life and Education
metadata.synopsis: Joshua Gay shares about his childhood in Hingham, Massachusetts, his large family, his early curiosity, entrepreneurial spirit, and unconventional path through school, including early jobs and unique learning style.
metadata.keywords: childhood, education, family, work ethic, entrepreneurship

metadata.title: Early Interests: Poetry and Programming
metadata.synopsis: Joshua discusses his teenage passion for poetry and how a friend's interest in Linux and calculator programming introduced him to computing. He also talks about early HTML and graphic design projects in high school.
metadata.keywords: poetry, programming, TI-82, HTML, graphic design, curiosity

metadata.title: Finding a Career Path
metadata.synopsis: Joshua initially aspired to be a millionaire and studied investing. After struggling academically, he strategically entered college as a computer science major to improve his acceptance chances, eventually discovering a passion and aptitude for programming.
metadata.keywords: career goals, computer science, college, motivation, academic challenges

metadata.title: First Industry Experience
metadata.synopsis: Joshua describes working at a startup called Super Wings, engaging in R&D, and dealing with proprietary software challenges. The experience deepened his interest in free software and sparked early philosophical reflections.
metadata.keywords: startup, R&D, programming, Java, proprietary software

metadata.title: Embracing Free Software and Collaborating with Stallman
metadata.synopsis: After Super Wings collapsed, Joshua fully committed to free software. He corresponded with Richard Stallman, leading to the creation of the book "Free Software, Free Society," gaining deep exposure to the GNU philosophy and community.
metadata.keywords: free software, Richard Stallman, GNU, publishing, philosophy

metadata.title: Philosophy of Free Software and New Applications
metadata.synopsis: Joshua reflects on learning the free software philosophy, its practical applications, and its broader societal implications. He discusses connecting with Lawrence Lessig and applying free software principles beyond code.
metadata.keywords: philosophy, GNU, Lawrence Lessig, Creative Commons, learning

metadata.title: The Free Textbook Project
metadata.synopsis: Joshua shares the origins and goals of his Free Textbook Project, aimed at creating modular, open-licensed educational materials. Though the project didn’t launch fully, it led to his involvement with similar efforts.
metadata.keywords: education, open textbooks, modular content, vision, learning tools

metadata.title: Textbook Revolution
metadata.synopsis: Building on his interest in open education, Joshua takes over the Textbook Revolution blog, compiling and promoting free textbooks and educational resources, creating an influential online hub for open learning.
metadata.keywords: textbooks, open education, OER, advocacy, self-learning

metadata.title: Post-College Path and Publishing Work
metadata.synopsis: After college, Joshua moves to NYC, pursues jobs in publishing and software, and attempts to pitch open textbook ideas. He joins small publishing and software firms, continuing his advocacy for open source.
metadata.keywords: publishing, career, free education, New York, early jobs

metadata.title: Early Programming Jobs and Challenges
metadata.synopsis: Joshua recounts technical work at Harris Corporation, where he introduced Python scripts to improve old systems, and how those experiences inspired further pursuit of computer science research and open source.
metadata.keywords: Harris Corporation, systems programming, legacy code, Python, innovation

metadata.title: Grad School and the Commons Development Foundation
metadata.synopsis: Joshua and his wife attend the University of Oklahoma. He starts the Commons Development Foundation, explores civic tech tools, and begins laying the groundwork for LibrePlanet and other open collaboration efforts.
metadata.keywords: graduate school, civic tech, nonprofit, LibrePlanet, open collaboration

metadata.title: Launching LibrePlanet and Joining FSF
metadata.synopsis: Joshua proposes and launches LibrePlanet while also organizing hackathons and working on free textbook proposals. He joins the Free Software Foundation (FSF) as a campaigns manager.
metadata.keywords: LibrePlanet, FSF, activism, free software community, organizing

metadata.title: Working at the Free Software Foundation
metadata.synopsis: Joshua describes FSF’s internal structure, its shift from CD sales to membership models, and how unionization helped define work boundaries, particularly regarding interactions with Richard Stallman.
metadata.keywords: FSF, organizational change, union, workplace culture, structure

metadata.title: Campaigning and Consumer Awareness
metadata.synopsis: Joshua talks about his role in building FSF’s campaigns team, raising awareness about software freedom, and how digital rights conversations evolved to be more mainstream and relatable.
metadata.keywords: campaigns, consumer rights, digital freedom, FSF mission, advocacy

metadata.title: Respect Your Freedom and Supporting Developers
metadata.synopsis: Joshua details launching FSF’s hardware certification program, supporting developers, and the broader goal of fostering ethical hardware businesses that align with free software principles.
metadata.keywords: hardware, certification, Respect Your Freedom, entrepreneurship, FSF impact

metadata.title: Joining CK12 Foundation and Scaling Open Education
metadata.synopsis: Joshua joins CK12 Foundation to build a platform for open, customizable K-12 textbooks. He bridges technical and editorial teams and supports the adoption of free educational resources in schools.
metadata.keywords: CK12, open education, modular content, platform development, textbooks

metadata.title: Mozilla, Open Badges, and Peer-to-Peer Learning
metadata.synopsis: After CK12, Joshua works with Mozilla and Peer2Peer University on Open Badges, metadata standards, and open learning pathways. He helps connect informal learning to formal recognition.
metadata.keywords: Mozilla, Open Badges, informal learning, metadata, education innovation

metadata.title: Licensing and Compliance at FSF
metadata.synopsis: Returning to FSF, Joshua manages licensing and compliance, helping individuals and organizations navigate GPL and advocating for license compatibility, influencing standards and policy.
metadata.keywords: GPL, licensing, compliance, FSF, policy, legal support

metadata.title: Bridging Standards and Free Software
metadata.synopsis: Joshua works on licensing compatibility with Creative Commons, microformats in HTML5, and other initiatives that connect software freedom to global infrastructure and digital policy.
metadata.keywords: standards, interoperability, Creative Commons, licensing, policy

metadata.title: Transition to IEEE and Standards Work
metadata.synopsis: Joshua leaves FSF to join the IEEE Standards Association, where he brings free software principles into standards development. His unique background positions him to support both open source and global standardization.
metadata.keywords: IEEE, standards, open source integration, licensing, career transition

metadata.title: IEEE’s Mission and Culture
metadata.synopsis: Joshua explains IEEE’s mission to promote technology for humanity, its history, and its passionate global volunteer community. He reflects on how IEEE aligns with his values and long-term goals.
metadata.keywords: IEEE, engineering, volunteerism, global collaboration, mission-driven

metadata.title: How the Community Has Changed
metadata.synopsis: Joshua reflects on the legitimacy and acceptance of free and open source software, noting a major shift from skepticism to widespread understanding and integration into society and business.
metadata.keywords: community evolution, acceptance, open source, legitimacy, public awareness

metadata.title: Open Source 2.0 and Broader Adoption
metadata.synopsis: He discusses the broader adoption of open source principles in academic and institutional contexts, and how the community now tackles large-scale societal challenges like climate change.
metadata.keywords: open source 2.0, academia, climate tech, evolution, interdisciplinary

metadata.title: A Message to Future Generations
metadata.synopsis: Joshua shares heartfelt reflections for future generations, emphasizing the importance of community, collaboration, and staying grounded in humanity while solving technical problems.
metadata.keywords: legacy, humanity, collaboration, purpose, future message

metadata.title: Final Reflections and Gratitude
metadata.synopsis: Joshua expresses gratitude for the opportunity to share his story, reflects on the community’s importance in his career, and appreciates the Free and Open Source Stories project.
metadata.keywords: gratitude, storytelling, community support, reflection, inspiration
